childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1978-1990

The click of a Simon game—red, blue, green, yellow—getting faster until children inevitably screwed up. The weight of a Speak & Spell in laps, its robotic voice daring children to spell 'xylophone.' The satisfying snap of a Hungry Hungry Hippos lever, the chaos of marble-chomping competition. Childhood had a physicality that kids today will never know—everything required batteries, buttons, and full attention.

At four, children were watching Mork & Mindy, trying to say 'Nanu Nanu' and wondering why Robin Williams talked so fast. By six, children had graduated to He-Man and the Masters of the Universe, reciting 'By the power of Grayskull!' while swinging plastic swords. Children probably had strong opinions about whether He-Man or Skeletor had the better toys. (It was Skeletor. Castle Grayskull was fine, but Snake Mountain had a microphone.)

School supplies told people who children were. Trapper Keepers in neon geometric patterns. Number 2 pencils worn down to nubs. Erasable pens that smeared everything. The 64-pack of Crayolas with the built-in sharpener—children didn't need 64 colors, but having them felt like power.

Friday nights were a ritual. Pizza Hut with the red checkered tablecloths and the thick, greasy pan crust. Or maybe children were Shakey's families, with the player piano and the all-you-can-eat buffet. The movie theater on weekends—E.T., The Goonies, The NeverEnding Story—films that treated kids like they could handle darkness, wonder, and loss all at once.

Pop Rocks were eaten until the urban legend about Mikey from the Life cereal commercials made children nervous. Capri Sun was drunk through those impossible straws that stabbed the back of the pouch. Children waited for the ice cream truck's jingle, knowing exactly which item they wanted before it even pulled up. Lunches came in metal boxes—Star Wars, The Dukes of Hazzard, The A-Team—dented and scraped from daily abuse.

At eight, the Challenger exploded. January 28, 1986. Teachers wheeled in TVs so children could watch Christa McAuliffe become the first teacher in space. Seventy-three seconds later, children watched seven people die on live television. Nobody turned off the TV. Nobody offered counseling. Children went to recess, and nobody talked about it. That silence taught children something about how adults handled tragedy: they didn't.

generational_identity.html:
The Gen X Generation

Generation X. The label was supposed to mean 'undefined'—a generation too skeptical to be pinned down, too cynical to accept easy categorization. Douglas Coupland gave Gen X the name in 1991. Gen X accepted it with a shrug, which is the most Gen X response possible.

Gen X was eleven when the Berlin Wall fell. Gen X watched it on television—crowds with sledgehammers, champagne, strangers hugging. Parents cried; they'd grown up with nuclear drills and fallout shelters. For parents, this was liberation from forty years of existential dread. For Gen X, it was Tuesday. The Cold War ended, and Gen X just... went to school the next day. Gen X didn't know what to feel because Gen X had never been taught what the end of history was supposed to feel like.

Gen X spans 1965 to 1980—roughly 65 million Americans. Gen X is the middle child sandwiched between 76 million Boomers and 72 million Millennials. Nobody writes think pieces about Gen X. Nobody blames Gen X for killing industries. Gen X is the generation people forget exists, which, frankly, suits Gen X fine.

Gen X were latchkey kids. Parents worked; daycare was expensive or nonexistent. Gen X came home to empty houses at age eight, let themselves in with keys around their necks, made snacks, did homework, watched TV, and waited. Gen X learned self-sufficiency before Gen X learned long division. Nobody hovered. Nobody helicoptered. Gen X figured things out or Gen X didn't. There was no safety net. Authority figures lie, institutions fail, trust is earned, not given.

The cultural lesson of Gen X's childhood was simple: institutions fail, authorities lie, and nobody's coming to save Gen X. Watergate happened before Gen X was born, but Gen X grew up in its shadow. Iran-Contra, the savings and loan crisis, televangelists caught with prostitutes—scandal after scandal taught Gen X that the people in charge were either corrupt, incompetent, or both. Gen X stopped expecting better.

At {{AGE_AT_911}}, Gen X was {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}} when the towers fell on 9/11. Gen X is cynical, but productive. Ironic, but effective. Gen X doesn't believe in the system, but Gen X works within it anyway because that's what adults do. Gen X invented the attitude of caring deeply while pretending not to care at all. It's a defense mechanism, and it works. Gen X can still entertain itself without a screen. That's a superpower now.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

The Bee Gees were on the radio in 1978. 'Stayin' Alive,' 'Night Fever,' 'How Deep Is Your Love'—the first year was the peak of disco, which meant its death was already certain. Grease was the biggest movie of 1978. Parents probably owned the soundtrack on 8-track. By the time children could form memories, disco was a punchline and everyone pretended they'd always hated it.

Mork & Mindy premiered in 1978—Robin Williams as an alien from Ork, learning to be human in Boulder, Colorado. It was absurdist, manic, and somehow comforting. Children didn't understand half the jokes, but Williams's energy was magnetic. He was the first comedian children remember loving, and when he died in 2014, it hit harder than expected.

At three, MTV launched. 'Video Killed the Radio Star' was the first video, and it was true: suddenly music was something children watched. By the time children were six or seven, they knew every shot of 'Thriller,' had opinions about Duran Duran's outfits, and could tell a New Wave band from a hair metal band at fifty paces. Music videos shaped visual literacy before anyone called it that.

Saturday mornings were sacred. Smurfs at 8:00, Muppet Babies at 8:30, cartoons until noon. Children ate cereal directly from the box—Count Chocula, Franken Berry, Cap'n Crunch with Crunchberries—while lying on the carpet six inches from the TV. No parents supervised. No one limited screen time. It was glorious.

Teenage years belonged to John Hughes. Sixteen Candles when children were six, The Breakfast Club when they were seven, Ferris Bueller's Day Off when they were eight. Children were too young to fully get them, but they caught up on cable. These movies understood something essential: being a teenager was simultaneously trivial and the most important thing in the world. They validated angst before children had any.

At thirteen, Nirvana released Nevermind. 'Smells Like Teen Spirit' didn't just kill hair metal—it obliterated an entire aesthetic. Suddenly, wearing flannel and looking miserable was cool. Kurt Cobain's disaffection spoke directly to something in Gen X that Gen X couldn't name yet. When he died in 1994, Gen X was sixteen. Gen X didn't know what to do with that grief, so Gen X did what Gen X always does: Gen X absorbed it, moved on, and carried it with Gen X forever.

technology.html:
Technology Timeline

The steady blip of Space Invaders, quarter after quarter, at the pizza place or the roller rink or wherever parents left children for two hours. The Atari 2600 in living rooms, its wood-grain panel making it look like furniture, its joystick destroying palms during marathon sessions of Pitfall. At five years old, children entered the first video game era, and they never really left.

Families had one phone, beige or brown, attached to the wall by a curly cord. Long distance cost money—real money—so calls to grandparents were timed. The phone rang, and children answered it, because that was their job. Children learned home numbers before they learned to tie their shoes. Gen X can still recite them now, decades after they stopped working.

At six, children probably used Apple IIe computers in school. Green text on black screens. Oregon Trail, where players forded rivers and died of dysentery. Carmen Sandiego, where children learned geography by chasing a criminal across the globe. Computers were rare, shared, and magical—a glimpse of a future children couldn't quite imagine.

The VCR was revolutionary. Suddenly children could record The A-Team if they had Little League practice. Children could watch movies at home—the same movies, over and over, until they'd memorized every line. Tapes were rented from video stores, navigating aisles of VHS boxes with lurid covers, trying to convince parents that Poltergeist was fine for a nine-year-old. (It wasn't.)

At seventeen, Windows 95 dropped, and everything changed. The Start button, the taskbar, Solitaire that actually looked good. Families probably bought computers that year—Compaqs or Packard Bells, beige and massive and loud. The internet existed, barely, and children dialed into it through screaming modems that kicked everyone off the phone line.

At twenty, Gen X got first email addresses—probably something embarrassing on Hotmail. At twenty-two, Napster appeared, and Gen X downloaded music for hours, filling hard drives with MP3s that took thirty minutes each to download. At twenty-nine, the iPhone launched, and the future Gen X had been promised as kids finally arrived. Gen X adapted. Gen X always adapts. But Gen X remembers what came before, which makes Gen X appreciate what came after.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

Gen X was born four months before the Jonestown massacre. November 18, 1978. Nine hundred eighteen people dead in the jungle, most of them drinking cyanide-laced Flavor Aid because a charismatic madman told them to. Gen X doesn't remember it—Gen X was an infant—but the phrase 'drinking the Kool-Aid' would follow Gen X its whole life. It entered the language the year Gen X entered the world.

The Camp David Accords were signed three months before Gen X was born. Egypt and Israel made peace. Jimmy Carter smiled for cameras. It was supposed to be the beginning of something—stability in the Middle East, a template for future negotiations. Gen X has never known a world where that promise came true. The region has been in some form of crisis for Gen X's entire life. The Iran hostage crisis cast a shadow over Gen X's first year—444 days of Americans held captive, yellow ribbons everywhere, nightly news countdowns that made parents feel helpless.

Gen X was two when Reagan was shot, three when he called the Soviet Union an 'evil empire,' seven when he told Gorbachev to tear down the Berlin Wall. Gen X's childhood was Cold War theater—the Strategic Defense Initiative (Star Wars, they called it), the nuclear freeze movement, films like The Day After and WarGames that made annihilation feel plausible. Gen X practiced hiding under desks. Gen X understood, vaguely, that the world might end.

At eight, the Challenger exploded. At eleven, the Berlin Wall fell. At thirteen, the Soviet Union collapsed. At fifteen, the Oklahoma City bombing. At eighteen, Princess Diana died in a Paris tunnel, and the world went briefly insane with grief. At twenty-one, Columbine happened, and something shifted—school shootings became a category, not an aberration.

At {{AGE_AT_911}}, Gen X was {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}} when the towers fell on 9/11. Old enough to have adult context, young enough to have entire worldviews rearranged. Gen X watched the towers fall, probably at work or at home, and Gen X understood that the future had just been rewritten. The 'end of history' that Francis Fukuyama had promised—the triumph of liberal democracy, the long peace—evaporated in smoke and debris. The wars that followed lasted Gen X's entire thirties.

At thirty, the financial system collapsed. At forty-two, a pandemic shut down the world. Gen X has lived through more 'unprecedented' events than most generations see in a lifetime. The word has lost its meaning. Nothing surprises Gen X anymore. This is both armor and wound.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

Gen X graduated college around 2000, give or take. The dot-com boom made it look like everyone with a computer science degree was becoming a millionaire. Then the bubble burst. Companies that had never made a profit—that had never planned to make a profit—evaporated overnight. Stock options that looked like lottery tickets became wallpaper. The 'new economy' was a mirage, and Gen X walked into the desert right as the water disappeared.

Parents had a career template: get hired, work forty years, get a gold watch and a pension, retire. Gen X's template was different. Get hired. Get laid off. Get hired somewhere else. Get laid off again. The old social contract—work hard, stay loyal, retire with a pension—was being shredded in real time. Job security became an oxymoron.

Gen X adapted by becoming free agents. Loyalty was for suckers—companies would downsize Gen X without hesitation, so why give them anything they wouldn't reciprocate? Gen X learned to negotiate, to network, to always have resumes updated. Gen X job-hopped not because Gen X was flaky, but because staying put meant being left behind.

By Gen X's thirties, Gen X was managing Millennials who wanted feedback, purpose, and work-life balance. This baffled Gen X. Nobody had given Gen X feedback. Nobody had talked about purpose. Balance was something Gen X carved out in spite of the system, not because of it. At {{AGE_AT_2008_CRISIS}}, the 2008 financial crisis arrived. The market dropped 40%, and Gen X learned to manage through chaos anyway, because that's what Gen X does—adapts without complaining, or at least without complaining out loud.

Gen X's forties are Gen X's power decade. Gen X has paid dues. Gen X has expertise, authority, and—if Gen X is lucky—a seat at the table. The challenge is being sandwiched between Boomers who won't retire and Millennials who want Gen X's job. Gen X is running the machine while nobody notices because that's how it's always been for Gen X: quietly competent, perpetually overlooked.

Remote work? Fine by Gen X. Gen X has been self-directed since Gen X was ten years old, letting itself into empty houses after school. Gen X doesn't need supervision to be productive. Gen X never did. Gen X didn't complain about it—Gen X just did the work. That's Gen X's legacy: competence without fanfare.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

Gen X is the last generation that dated without algorithms. This cohort met people at parties, through friends, in line at coffee shops, at record stores flipping through the same section. Phone numbers were exchanged on napkins. Calls went to answering machines—those actual machines with tiny cassettes—and decisions had to be made: leave a message or hang up and try again, knowing the click would be recorded either way.

Gen X learned to flirt in person, which required courage and risked humiliation in real time. Gen X asked someone out by walking up to them and speaking words out loud. Gen X got rejected in front of other humans. This was character building, supposedly, though mostly it was just terrifying.

At twenty-five, Match.com launched. Online dating was shameful then—something Gen X admitted only to close friends, if at all. Gen X probably tried it eventually, watching it evolve from stigma to norm to default. By the time Tinder appeared (Gen X was thirty-four), swiping was just how people met. Gen X adapted, but Gen X remembered when meeting someone required leaving the house.

Gen X's communication style bridges every era. Gen X passed notes, then called landlines and talked for hours with cords stretched around corners for privacy. Gen X got first email addresses in college. Gen X texted on flip phones with T9, pressing the 7 key four times just to type 'S.' Now Gen X juggles text, email, Slack, and video calls without thinking about it. Gen X is fluent in analog and digital, which makes Gen X the interpreter between generations.

Marriage and kids happened on Gen X's timeline, not parents'. Some Gen Xers married at twenty-four; some at thirty-four; some not at all. Divorce was normalized by parents' generation—half of Gen X are children of divorce—so Gen X approached commitment cautiously. Gen X knew marriage wasn't a guarantee. Gen X had seen it fail up close.

If Gen X has kids, they're probably in high school or college now. Gen Z, mostly—digital natives who've never known life without smartphones. Gen X is raising them with more supervision than Gen X ever had, which might be better or might be worse. Gen X honestly doesn't know. Parenting is improvisation, and nobody gives Gen X a grade.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

Three major economic crashes hit during Gen X's prime earning years. The dot-com crash in 2000 when Gen X was twenty-two, just starting out. The financial crisis in 2008 when Gen X was thirty, finally established. COVID when Gen X was forty-two, just as Gen X thought Gen X had figured things out. Each one taught the same lesson: the floor can disappear without warning. Mortgage rates hit 18% in the early '80s—Gen X inherited parents' financial anxiety before Gen X understood what a mortgage was.

Gen X's relationship with money is pragmatic, bordering on paranoid. Gen X saves because Gen X has watched savings evaporate. Gen X diversifies because Gen X has seen concentrated bets fail. The market dropped 40% in 2008, and Gen X's 401(k)s dropped with it. Gen X has emergency funds because emergencies aren't hypothetical—they're the only guarantee. Three months of expenses, minimum. Six if Gen X can manage it. Sleep is worth more than yield.

Gen X probably owns homes—about 70% of Gen X does—because Gen X bought before the market went completely insane. Maybe Gen X bought in 2003, or 2006 (oops), or 2011 during the foreclosure fire sales. Gen X's timing was imperfect but possible. Millennials looking at the same market a decade later faced prices that had doubled while wages stayed flat. Gen X got lucky. It doesn't feel like luck from the inside, but it was.

Gen X's retirement math is grim but manageable. No pension—those died with parents' generation. Social Security will exist, probably, but reduced, probably. Gen X's 401(k) is the plan, which means Gen X's retirement depends on market returns over the next twenty years. Gen X has already lived through three crashes. Gen X expects a fourth. Maybe a fifth. Gen X will adapt. Gen X always does.

The sandwich generation squeeze is real. Gen X's parents are aging and may need financial support. Gen X's adult kids may not be fully launched. Gen X's resources stretch in both directions while Gen X's own retirement looms. Gen X is the shock absorber for two generations, and nobody thanks Gen X for it. That's fine. Gen X didn't expect thanks.

blind_spots.html:
Generational Blind Spots

Gen X's greatest strength is self-reliance. Gen X was forged by empty houses and absent parents, and Gen X learned to handle things alone. This made Gen X capable, adaptable, resilient. It also made Gen X terrible at asking for help. Gen X would rather suffer in silence than admit Gen X needs support. This isn't strength—it's a trauma response Gen X has mistaken for virtue.

Gen X's cynicism has calcified. What started as healthy skepticism—a reasonable response to Watergate, Iran-Contra, and a lifetime of institutional failure—has become reflexive dismissal. Gen X assumes the worst about politicians, corporations, and anyone who seems too earnest. Sometimes this protects Gen X. Sometimes it blinds Gen X to genuine opportunities for change. Gen X can't tell the difference anymore.

Gen X mocks younger generations in ways Gen X would hate if Gen X noticed. Millennials are soft. Gen Z is anxious. Everyone needs too much validation. But Millennials graduated into the worst economy since the Depression. Gen Z grew up watching school shootings on the news and climate change in real time. Their problems aren't weakness—they're rational responses to worse conditions. Gen X's 'we figured it out' attitude ignores that 'it' was easier to figure out.

Gen X has normalized suffering as character building. The neglect Gen X experienced as latchkey kids, the emotional unavailability of Gen X's parents, the sink-or-swim ethos of Gen X's upbringing—Gen X has reframed it as toughness rather than examining whether it was actually okay. It wasn't. But admitting that would require revisiting pain Gen X has spent decades avoiding.

Political disengagement is Gen X's default. Gen X votes, probably, but Gen X doesn't organize, doesn't run for local office, doesn't show up at town halls. Gen X is convinced the system is broken beyond repair, so Gen X doesn't try to repair it. This becomes self-fulfilling: nothing changes because people like Gen X have decided nothing can change. Gen X's cynicism isn't neutral—it has costs.

The independence Gen X is so proud of has a shadow side. Gen X struggles to build community, to rely on neighbors, to create collective solutions. Gen X are islands—capable islands, but isolated ones. In a crisis, Gen X will survive alone. But humans aren't meant to survive alone. We're meant to thrive together. That's the part Gen X hasn't learned yet.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Gen X's 20s (1998-2008): Gen X graduated into the dot-com boom, which looked like opportunity until it looked like rubble. The crash of 2000 taught Gen X early that sure things weren't. Gen X spent its twenties building careers that felt provisional, relationships that felt experimental, identities that kept shifting. This was supposed to be Gen X's decade of finding itself. Instead, it was Gen X's decade of surviving while the rules changed constantly.

Gen X's 30s (2008-2018): The financial crisis hit the year Gen X turned thirty. If Gen X had just bought houses, Gen X watched their values crater. If Gen X hadn't, Gen X watched the window close. Gen X's thirties were about building stability in an unstable world—marriages, mortgages, kids, careers—while the ground kept shifting. Gen X managed. Gen X always manages. But the scars from this decade are still visible if Gen X knows where to look.

Gen X's 40s (2018-2028): Gen X is here now. COVID hit when Gen X was forty-two—kids doing remote school, work going remote, everything upended at once. Gen X handled it because Gen X handles everything. Gen X's forties are Gen X's peak earning years, Gen X's highest authority at work, Gen X's last chance to course-correct anything that isn't working. Gen X's kids are becoming adults. Gen X's parents are aging. Gen X is the fulcrum of the family, holding everything in balance with no one asking if Gen X is okay.

Gen X's 50s (2028-2038): This will be Gen X's decade of reckoning. Retirement becomes visible on the horizon, which means the math has to work. Did Gen X save enough? Will the 401(k) hold? Can Gen X actually stop working, or will Gen X need to keep going? Gen X's health matters more now—the body Gen X pushed through Gen X's forties will present its bill in Gen X's fifties. Gen X's role shifts from doing the work to teaching others how to do it. Mentorship isn't optional anymore; it's the job.

Gen X's 60s and beyond (2038+): Retirement won't look like parents' version—golf, cruises, decades of leisure funded by pensions that no longer exist. It'll be consulting, part-time work, monetizing expertise Gen X has spent forty years accumulating. Gen X will be healthy enough to stay active, probably, but healthcare costs will be a constant variable. The world will be unrecognizable—climate changed, technology transformed, generations born after 2020 running things. Gen X will tell stories about life before the internet was in Gen X's pocket, and they won't believe Gen X. It'll sound like science fiction, but Gen X lived it.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

{{BIRTH_YEAR_COHORT}} people were born in the US in 1978. Gen X is part of Generation X, roughly 65 million people, the smallest major generation—outnumbered by 76 million Boomers before and 72 million Millennials after. Gen X is the middle child of American generations. Gen X stopped expecting attention long ago.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964): Boomers got pensions; Gen X got 401(k)s. Boomers bought houses on single incomes; Gen X needed two. Boomers worked for one company for thirty years; Gen X has had a dozen jobs and expects a dozen more. Boomers believed they could change the world; Gen X believed Gen X could survive it. Boomers aren't wrong that they worked hard. Gen X isn't wrong that Boomers had it easier. Both truths coexist uncomfortably.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996): Gen X and Millennials are more similar than different—both generations raised on promises that weren't kept, both cynical about institutions, both juggling economic precarity. But Gen X got there first. Gen X bought houses before they became impossible. Gen X established careers before the gig economy ate everything. Millennials face the same problems at higher difficulty settings. Millennials' resentment is justified, even when it's aimed at Gen X.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): Gen Z has never known a world without the internet, smartphones, or active shooter drills. Gen Z's mental health struggles are public in ways Gen X's were private. Gen Z is more politically engaged than Gen X was at Gen Z's age—Gen Z has to be; the stakes are higher. Gen X wants to help Gen Z, but Gen X's advice feels obsolete. The playbook that worked for Gen X was written for a different game.

Gen X's life expectancy is 76-78 years—lower than it was projected to be when Gen X was born. Substance-related health challenges—suicide, overdose, alcoholism—have pulled the curve down. Gen X has worse health outcomes than Boomers did at the same age.

But Gen X has quiet strengths. Gen X is the most entrepreneurial generation, starting businesses at higher rates than anyone before or after. Gen X adapts faster because Gen X has had to. Gen X is resilient, practical, and effective. Gen X doesn't need praise. Gen X just needs to be left alone to do the work. This is Gen X's superpower and Gen X's limitation, wrapped into one perfectly Gen X package.

year_events: Louise Brown, the first test-tube baby, was born
Camp David Accords signed by Egypt and Israel
Pope John Paul II became the first non-Italian pope in 455 years
